articles.headline: U.S. Issues Limits on Greenhouse Gas Emissions From Cars
articles.snippet: The federal government’s rules set mileage standards that will translate to a combined fuel economy average for new vehicles of 35.5 miles per gallon.
articles.abstract: The federal government’s rules set mileage standards that will translate to a combined fuel economy average for new vehicles of 35.5 miles per gallon.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government took its first formal step to regulate global warming pollution on Thursday by issuing final rules for greenhouse gas emissions for automobiles and light trucks.

articles.headline: Coming Visit May Signal Easing by China on Currency
articles.snippet: Word of President Hu Jintao’s visit to Washington comes amid a debate over how far China’s currency should rise.
articles.abstract: Word of President Hu Jintao’s visit to Washington comes amid a debate over how far China’s currency should rise.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is the number that lurks behind much of modern economic life, a figure that helps shape the fortunes of nations and the price of nearly everything.

articles.headline: Iran Plays Host to Delegations After Iraq Elections
articles.snippet: The U.S. has tried to stay out of the process of forming Iraq’s new government. Iran has shown no such qualms.
articles.abstract: The U.S. has tried to stay out of the process of forming Iraq’s new government. Iran has shown no such qualms.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iran may seem an unlikely place to turn for guidance when it comes to putting together a democratic government, but that is exactly what most of Iraq’s political class did immediately after last month’s parliamentary elections.

articles.headline: Demystify the Lehman Shell Game
articles.snippet: If regulators find that banks other than Lehman used repos to hide leverage, many more questions will follow.
articles.abstract: If regulators find that banks other than Lehman used repos to hide leverage, many more questions will follow.
articles.lead_paragraph: Making unattractive assets disappear from corporate balance sheets was one of the great magical tricks performed by accountants over the last few decades.

articles.headline: From Lithuania, a View of Austerity’s Costs
articles.snippet: As European nations consider the social and political costs of cutting public sector spending, Lithuania offers a case study of the societal trade-offs.
articles.abstract: As European nations consider the social and political costs of cutting public sector spending, Lithuania offers a case study of the societal trade-offs.
articles.lead_paragraph: VILNIUS, Lithuania — If leaders of the world’s many indebted countries want to see what austerity looks like, they might want to visit this Baltic nation of 3.3 million.

articles.headline: Pay Garnishments Rise as Debtors Fall Behind
articles.snippet: Because many consumers don’t offer a defense in court, creditors can win big judgments by default.
articles.abstract: Because many consumers don’t offer a defense in court, creditors can win big judgments by default.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — When the bank sued Leann Weaver for not paying her credit card balance, her reaction was typical for someone in that situation. Personal and financial setbacks weighed her down, and she knew she owed the $2,470. So she never went to court to defend herself.

articles.headline: Questions for School on Bullying and a Suicide
articles.snippet: School officials in South Hadley, Mass., dispute claims they had long known about the hazing of a 15-year-old.
articles.abstract: School officials in South Hadley, Mass., dispute claims they had long known about the hazing of a 15-year-old.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass. — On one point, everyone here agrees: the high school students who taunted and threatened Phoebe Prince for three months, until she hanged herself, deserve to be punished.
articles.byline: By Erik Eckholm and Katie Zezima

articles.headline: Doing the iPad Math: Utility + Price + Desire
articles.snippet: For all the exuberance surrounding Apple’s new iPad, many consumers do not understand the device’s purpose, and some say they don’t need yet another gadget.
articles.abstract: For all the exuberance surrounding Apple’s new iPad, many consumers do not understand the device’s purpose, and some say they don’t need yet another gadget.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the much-promoted iPad is going to be a mainstream consumer hit, Apple is going to have to change the minds of people like Jon Byron.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Security Checks on Flights to U.S. to Be Revamped
articles.snippet: The new approach will replace the extra scrutiny that had been imposed on passengers from 14 countries.
articles.abstract: The new approach will replace the extra scrutiny that had been imposed on passengers from 14 countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has signed off on new security protocols for people flying to the United States, establishing a system that uses intelligence information and assessment of threats to identify passengers who could have links to terrorism, a senior administration official said Thursday.

articles.headline: Russia Says Suicide Bomber Was Militant’s Widow
articles.snippet: Officials said one of two bombers in the Moscow subway attacks was the 17-year-old widow of an insurgent.
articles.abstract: Officials said one of two bombers in the Moscow subway attacks was the 17-year-old widow of an insurgent.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Baby-faced, she looks barely a teenager. But the pistol she is holding in the photograph suggests the violent destiny that she would choose: blowing herself up in a subway station in Moscow during the morning rush on Monday.
articles.byline: By Clifford J. Levy and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Signaling Jobs Recovery, Payrolls Surged in March
articles.snippet: Starting to reverse the loss of eight million jobs, American employers took on 162,000 more workers in March.
articles.abstract: Starting to reverse the loss of eight million jobs, American employers took on 162,000 more workers in March.
articles.byline: By Catherine Rampell and Javier C. Hernández

articles.headline: Health Law Preserves Cobra Plan
articles.snippet: Cobra benefits are available — though subsidies have run out, they may be restored — and there are private insurance plans and state-run programs for children.
articles.abstract: Cobra benefits are available — though subsidies have run out, they may be restored — and there are private insurance plans and state-run programs for children.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’ve recently joined the ranks of the unemployed or are worried that you soon will, you may be wondering if the sweeping new health law will help you. Will you, for instance, still be able to get health insurance under the government-mandated Cobra program? If so, for how long? And at what price?
